sentences: Jason Sean Donovan (born 1 June 1968) is an Australian actor and singer.
section: N/A

sentences: He initially achieved fame in the Australian soap Neighbours, playing Scott Robinson, before beginning a career in music in 1988.
section: N/A

sentences: In the UK he has sold over 3 million records.
section: N/A

sentences: His debut album Ten Good Reasons was the highest-selling album in the UK in 1989, with sales of over 1.5 million.
section: N/A

sentences: He has had four UK No. 1 singles, one of which was "Especially for You", his 1988 duet with fellow Neighbours co-star Kylie Minogue.
section: N/A

sentences: He has also appeared in several stage musicals, most prominently in the lead role of Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat in the early 1990s.
section: N/A
== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Jason Donovan was born on 1 June 1968 in the Melbourne suburb Malvern, Victoria.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He is the son of Australian actress Sue McIntosh (née Menlove) and British-born veteran stage and television actor Terence Donovan (who also appeared in Neighbours) who has English and Irish heritage.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Following his parents' separation and divorce, his father was awarded full custody of him in 1973 and brought him up on his own.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Donovan has had no contact with his mother since the divorce.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He attended De La Salle College Malvern.
section: == Early life ==

section: == Career == | === 1980–1989: Television career and Neighbours ===
== Career == | === 1980–1989: Television career and Neighbours ===

sentences: Donovan made his first television appearance at age 11 in a guest role on the Australian series Skyways in 1980.
section: == Career == | === 1980–1989: Television career and Neighbours ===

sentences: In the episode, his on-screen sister was played by future Neighbours co-star Kylie Minogue.
section: == Career == | === 1980–1989: Television career and Neighbours ===

sentences: He also appeared in the series I Can Jump Puddles (1981) and Golden Pennies (1985) before entering the cast of Neighbours in 1986 as Scott Robinson (replacing actor Darius Perkins, who had played the role for the first year of the series).
section: == Career == | === 1980–1989: Television career and Neighbours ===

sentences: His character's story arcs included an onscreen romance and wedding to Charlene Mitchell (played by Minogue), and helped boost the show's popularity with British as well as Australian audiences.
section: == Career == | === 1980–1989: Television career and Neighbours ===

sentences: He won his first Logie Award for "Best New Talent" in 1987 and received a commendation in the category "Performance by a Male Actor In a Series" from the Television Society of Australia's Penguin Awards.
section: == Career == | === 1980–1989: Television career and Neighbours ===

sentences: In 1988 he was awarded the Silver Logie for the "Most Popular Actor" on Australian television.
section: == Career == | === 1980–1989: Television career and Neighbours ===

sentences: In addition to his regular role in Neighbours, Donovan appeared as "Happy Houston" in the 1988 Australian World War II mini-series The Heroes, based on the historical novel by Ronald McKie.
section: == Career == | === 1980–1989: Television career and Neighbours ===

sentences: He won the 1990 Logie Award for "Most Popular Actor in a Mini-Series".
section: == Career == | === 1980–1989: Television career and Neighbours ===

sentences: Donovan left Neighbours in 1989.
section: == Career == | === 1980–1989: Television career and Neighbours ===

sentences: Twenty years later, he said that he had been asked to return to tie in with the show's 25th anniversary in 2010, but was unable to do so due to other work commitments.

sentences: Pop career =
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===
== Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: While he was still appearing in Neighbours, Donovan followed Minogue (who had already left the series by this point) in signing a recording contract with Mushroom Records in Australia, and with PWL in the UK.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: His first single, "Nothing Can Divide Us", was released in 1988.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: Like Minogue's material, it was written and produced by the production team of Stock Aitken Waterman.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: The single reached number five in the UK.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: Donovan's next single was a duet with Minogue.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: "Especially for You" was released in December 1988, and after spending four weeks at No. 2 in the UK, it hit No. 1 in January 1989.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: It was the fourth-highest selling single in the UK in 1988, and 17th in Australia for 1989.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: His next single, "Too Many Broken Hearts", reached number one in the UK in March 1989.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: He released his début album, Ten Good Reasons, in May 1989, which also reached number one (for three weeks).
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: For two weeks, Donovan held the number one positions in the singles chart and the albums chart simultaneously, when his next single, a cover of Brian Hyland's "Sealed With a Kiss", entered the UK charts at number one.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: In December 1989, he took part in Band Aid II's version of "Do They Know it's Christmas", which also included Minogue, whose exit from Neighbours had by now been shown on screen in both Australia and the UK.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: His own exit from the show had by this stage been shown on Australian television, although it was not aired on British television until several months later.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: Donovan released his second album, Between The Lines, in May 1990, again produced by Stock Aitken Waterman.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: Although the album reached Platinum status in the UK, it was less successful than his debut a year before, peaking at no. 2 and selling only a fifth as many copies.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: Five singles were released from the album, and although they all reached the UK Top 30, they also signalled a decline in his popularity.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: Between 1988 and 1992, Donovan garnered 16 Top 40 hit singles in the UK.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: He embarked on an extensive world tour in 1990, The "Doin' Fine Tour".
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: It covered the UK, Ireland, mainland Europe, Australia, Singapore and other parts of South East Asia.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: The Dublin concert was recorded and released on VHS in 1990; and released on DVD in 2010.
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

sentences: Donovan continued to act alongside his pop career, and in 1990 he appeared in his first feature film, Blood Oath (released in some countries as Prisoners of the Sun).
section: == Career == | === 1988–1991: Pop career ===

== Career == | === 1991–1993: Stage career and The Face lawsuit ===

sentences: Stage career and The Face lawsuit =
section: == Career == | === 1991–1993: Stage career and The Face lawsuit ===
== Career == | === 1991–1993: Stage career and The Face lawsuit ===

sentences: In 1991, Donovan accepted the lead role in the restaged London Palladium version of Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat, directed by Steven Pimlott.
section: == Career == | === 1991–1993: Stage career and The Face lawsuit ===

sentences: Donovan had his third solo UK No. 1 single with one of its songs, "Any Dream Will Do".
section: == Career == | === 1991–1993: Stage career and The Face lawsuit ===

sentences: Donovan left the production in early 1992.
section: == Career == | === 1991–1993: Stage career and The Face lawsuit ===

sentences: In 1992, Donovan launched a libel action against The Face magazine which had published allegations that he was homosexual.
section: == Career == | === 1991–1993: Stage career and The Face lawsuit ===

sentences: Donovan won £200,000 in damages and the magazine had to pay a further £100,000 in costs, but the lawsuit created a backlash with people accusing him of being homophobic.
section: == Career == | === 1991–1993: Stage career and The Face lawsuit ===

sentences: Although he had been a mild drug user who had smoked cannabis joints up until this point, in the months after his libel action Donovan began using cocaine.
section: == Career == | === 1991–1993: Stage career and The Face lawsuit ===

sentences: In a 2007 Marie Claire interview, and also in his 2007 autobiography Between The Lines: My Story Uncut, Donovan stated that suing The Face was the biggest mistake of his life.
section: == Career == | === 1991–1993: Stage career and The Face lawsuit ===

sentences: Donovan moved to Polydor Records and released his third album, All Around The World (1993).
section: == Career == | === 1991–1993: Stage career and The Face lawsuit ===

sentences: Drug addiction, The Last Bullet and continued musical work ===
section: == Career == | === 1995–1999: Drug addiction, The Last Bullet and continued musical work ===

sentences: Donovan later admitted that by 1995 he had a serious drug problem, taking around three grams of cocaine a day.
section: == Career == | === 1995–1999: Drug addiction, The Last Bullet and continued musical work ===

sentences: In early 1995, he attended model Kate Moss's 21st birthday party at The Viper Room in Los Angeles, where he suffered a drug overdose.
section: == Career == | === 1995–1999: Drug addiction, The Last Bullet and continued musical work ===

sentences: Later in 1995, Donovan starred in the Australian TV film The Last Bullet with Koji Tamaki, directed by Michael Pattison, which was set in World War II on the Pacific island of Borneo.
section: == Career == | === 1995–1999: Drug addiction, The Last Bullet and continued musical work ===

sentences: In 1998, Donovan took the lead role of Dr. Frank N. Furter in the UK touring production of The Rocky Horror Show, where he met stage manager Angela Malloch.
section: == Career == | === 1995–1999: Drug addiction, The Last Bullet and continued musical work ===

sentences: After the pair had a brief relationship, Malloch became pregnant and gave Donovan an ultimatum that he had to kick drugs once and for all if he wanted to be part of their child's life.
section: == Career == | === 1995–1999: Drug addiction, The Last Bullet and continued musical work ===

sentences: In late 1999, Donovan stated that he still used cocaine, saying: "I still have a joint and I still take coke, but not as much as I did two years ago."
section: == Career == | === 1995–1999: Drug addiction, The Last Bullet and continued musical work ===

sentences: In 2011, he stated that he has been drug-free since 2000, the year his first child was born.
section: == Career == | === 1995–1999: Drug addiction, The Last Bullet and continued musical work ===

sentences: In 2005, Donovan's mobile phone number was circulated around the web in Australia, due to an image that was taken in Sydney.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2006: Virgin Mobile phone controversy and participation in I'm a Celebrity... ===

sentences: It appeared that Donovan was trying to sell his car, and unwittingly released his mobile phone number to the public.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2006: Virgin Mobile phone controversy and participation in I'm a Celebrity... ===

sentences: From 10 September, his answering machine had a special message on it, because he was frustrated by the number of calls he was receiving.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2006: Virgin Mobile phone controversy and participation in I'm a Celebrity... ===

sentences: Virgin placed advertisements in several high-profile Australian newspapers, urging people not to call Donovan, one of their customers.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2006: Virgin Mobile phone controversy and participation in I'm a Celebrity... ===

sentences: Virgin Mobile later admitted the photos were part of a marketing ploy.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2006: Virgin Mobile phone controversy and participation in I'm a Celebrity... ===

sentences: Virgin also ran TV advertisements showing Donovan answering prank calls, asking the viewer not to call him, then displaying his number.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2006: Virgin Mobile phone controversy and participation in I'm a Celebrity... ===

sentences: Donovan took part in I'm a Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here!
section: == Career == | === 2005–2006: Virgin Mobile phone controversy and participation in I'm a Celebrity... ===

sentences: in 2006 and finished in 3rd place.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2006: Virgin Mobile phone controversy and participation in I'm a Celebrity... ===

sentences: While in the jungle, he became good friends with David Gest and Matt Willis.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2006: Virgin Mobile phone controversy and participation in I'm a Celebrity... ===

sentences: Donovan also took part in many Bushtucker Trials, which included wearing a helmet full of insects and playing a giant game of Operation.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2006: Virgin Mobile phone controversy and participation in I'm a Celebrity... ===

sentences: Donovan lost out on the King of the Jungle Crown to Matt Willis.
section: == Career == | === 2005–2006: Virgin Mobile phone controversy and participation in I'm a Celebrity... ===

sentences: Despite his loss, during an interview on The Steve Wright Show on BBC Radio 2 (January 2008), he claimed that his appearance on I'm a Celebrity... had revitalised his career.
